fields.function: Fermentative or photobiological evolution of H<sub>2</sub> using reduced ferredoxin as an electron donor.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Anoxic waters, soils, and sediments, gastrointestinal tracts
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Widespread in anaerobic bacteria and unicellular eukaryotes
fields.subunit_description:
HydA (catalytic subunit)
In organisation 4 and 5, the catalytic subunit is split into a large subunit (HydA) and small subunit (HydS)
In organisation 5, a cytochrome b subunit (HydH) is present
In organisation 6, the hydrogenase domain is fused to a nitrate reductase or sulfite reductase domain
fields.fes_clusters:
Organisation 1: Absent
Organisation 2: 2 [4Fe4S] clusters
Organisation 3: 3 [4Fe4S] clusters, 1 [2Fe2S] cluster
Organisation 4: 2 [4Fe4S] clusters
Organisation 5: 2 [4Fe4S] clusters
Organisation 6: 3 [4Fe4S] clusters, 1 [2Fe2S] cluster

fields.function: Bifurcates electrons from H<sub>2</sub> to NAD and ferredoxin. Reverse reaction can also occur resulting in reoxidation of redox carriers concomitant with fermentative H<sub>2</sub> evolution.

fields.function: Hydrogenotrophic respiration using sulfate, metal, or organohalide compounds as terminal electron acceptors. Enzyme transfers H2-liberated electrons through cytochrome c3 to terminal reductase.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Anoxic soils and sediments, marine waters, animal gastrointestinal tracts
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Widespread in sulfate-reducing Deltaproteobacteria and Firmicutes

CycA (cytochrome c3 subunit)

fields.function: Hydrogenotrophic respiration using sulfate, fumarate, nitrate, metals, and azo compounds as terminal electron acceptors. Enzyme transfers H<sub>2</sub>-liberated electrons through cytochromes to terminal reductase.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Anoxic soils and sediments, marine waters, animal gastrointestinal tracts
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Widespread in Deltaproteobacteria and Epsilonproteobacteria
fields.subunit_description:
HynB (hydrogenase large subunit)
HynA (hydrogenase small subunit)
HynC (cytochrome b subunit)
In Deltaproteobacteria, CycA (cytochrome c3 subunit) substitutes for HynC

fields.function: Hydrogenotrophic respiration using fumarate, sulfate, or metals as terminal electron acceptors. Route of electron transfer unresolved. Can also fermentatively evolve H<sub>2</sub> under hypoxia.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Animal gastrointestinal tracts, anoxic soils and sediments
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Widespread in Enterobacteria and various sulfate-reducing bacteria

fields.function: Hydrogenotrophic respiration using sulfur as terminal electron acceptor. Route of electron transfer unresolved. Complex can also evolve H<sub>2</sub> using sulfur-derived electrons possibly through reversed electron flow or electron-bifurcation.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Soil and aquatic systems with high sulfur content
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Present in phototrophic and chemotrophic bacteria capable of respiratory sulfur oxidation and reduction

fields.function: Unresolved role. Some enzymes mediate hydrogenotrophic respiration using O<sub>2</sub> as a terminal electron acceptor. Enzyme also linked to protection from reactive oxygen species, protection of nitrogenase protection, and recycling of nitrogenase-derived H<sub>2</sub>.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Various soil and aquatic environments
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Present in both aerobic soil bacteria (e.g. Actinobacteria) and anaerobic marine bacteria (e.g. Deltaproteobacteria)
fields.subunit_description:
HyoL (hydrogenase large subunit)
HyoS (hydrogenase small subunit)
HyoE (cytochrome b subunit)
fields.notes: This hydrogenase class has been minimally studied. Further genetic, physiological, and biochemical studies are required to understand its role and behaviour. There is some phylogenetic evidence that this class is polyphyletic and may in fact include several loosely-related hydrogenases with distinct roles.

fields.function: Hydrogenotrophic respiration using O<sub>2</sub> as terminal electron acceptor. Enzyme scavenges electrons from atmospheric H<sub>2</sub> to fuel respiratory chain during carbon-starvation. Route of electron transfer unresolved.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Upland soils, plant tissues, possibly surface waters
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Widespread among obligately aerobic soil bacteria, especially Actinobacteria, Acidobacteria, and Chloroflexi
fields.subunit_description:
HyhL (hydrogenase large subunit)
HyhS (hydrogenase small subunit) HyhE (putative iron-sulfur protein and proposed physiological electron acceptor)
fields.notes: The Robiginitalea biformata and Sulfolobus islandicus enzymes are relatively distantly related to the main group. No studies have yet tested whether these enzymes have a H2-scavenging role like other Group 1h [NiFe]-hydrogenases. They may instead represent founding members of a functionally-distinct lineage.

fields.function: Unconfirmed role. Likely to mediate hydrogenotrophic respiration using unresolved electron acceptor. Enzyme may transfer H2-liberated electrons through cyt b and quinone to unresolved terminal reductase.

VhzA (hydrogenase large subunit)
VhzG (hydrogenase small subunit)
VhzC (cytochrome b subunit)
fields.notes: This hydrogenase class has only been identified based on genomic predictions. It may behave similarly to the related Group 1a [NiFe]-hydrogenases. However, physiological, genetic, and biochemical studies are needed to describes its properties.

fields.taxonomic_distribution: Exclusive to Euryarchaeota of the order Archaeoglobales
fields.subunit_description:
VhzA (hydrogenase large subunit)
VhzG (hydrogenase small subunit)
VhzC (cytochrome b subunit)

fields.group: [NiFe] Group 2: Alternative and sensory H<sub>2</sub>-uptake [NiFe] hydrogenases
fields.function: H<sub>2</sub>-sensing in regulatory cascades. Enzyme transfers H<sub>2</sub>-liberated electrons to PAS domain. Associated redox change modulates histidine kinase activity and in turn the two-component system controlling expression of primary H<sub>2</sub>-uptake hydrogenases.

fields.taxonomic_distribution: Exclusive to aerobic Proteobacteria

HupU (hydrogenase small subunit)
HupK (histidine kinase)
Interacts with response regulator (HupR)

fields.group: [NiFe] Group 2: Alternative and sensory H<sub>2</sub>-uptake [NiFe] hydrogenases
fields.function: Undetermined role. May serve as H<sub>2</sub>-sensors in regulatory cascades. Enzyme predicted to transfer H<sub>2</sub>-liberated electrons to PAS domain. Associated redox change may modulate cyclic di-GMP production and in turn various cellular processes.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: In low abundance in various soil and aquatic samples
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Exclusive to Proteobacteria, including methanotrophic Gammaproteobacteria and sulfate-reducing Deltaproteobacteria
fields.subunit_description:
HurL (hydrogenase large subunit)
HurS (hydrogenase small subunit)
HurR (putative diguanylate cyclase and phosphodiesterase)
fields.notes: This hydrogenase class has only been identified based on genomic predictions. The genetic organisation of the operon encoding this enzyme strongly suggests a role in cyclic di-GMP production, but this needs to be validated through physiological, biochemical, and genetic studies.
fields.literature:
Genetics:

  • Greening, C., Biswas, A., Carere, C.R., Jackson, C.J., Taylor, M.C., Stott, M.B., Cook, G.M., and Morales, S.E. (2016) Genomic and metagenomic surveys of hydrogenase distribution indicate H2 is a widely utilised energy source for microbial growth and survival. ISME J. 10: 761-777.

fields.group: [NiFe] Group 2: Alternative and sensory H<sub>2</sub>-uptake [NiFe] hydrogenases
fields.function: Unresolved role. Enzyme may generate reductant for carbon fixation, support hydrogenotrophic sulfur respiration, or have a regulatory role.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: In low abundance in hot spring samples
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Exclusive to Aquificae and Epsilonproteobacteria
fields.subunit_description:
HuaL (hydrogenase large subunit)
HuaS (hydrogenase small subunit)
Some appear to be transcribed with helix-turn-helix proteins
fields.notes: This hydrogenase class has been minimally studied. Further genetic, physiological, and biochemical studies are required to understand its role and behaviour.

fields.group: [NiFe] Group 2: Alternative and sensory H<sub>2</sub>-uptake [NiFe] hydrogenases
fields.function: Undetermined role. Likely to mediate hydrogenotrophic respiration using O<sub>2</sub> as a terminal electron acceptor. Route of electron transfer unresolved.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Hydrothermal systems, other high temperature environments
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Exclusive to Crenarchaeota
fields.subunit_description:
HysL (hydrogenase large subunit)
HysS (hydrogenase small subunit)
fields.notes: This hydrogenase class has only been identified based on genomic predictions. Its presence is correlated with the ability of crenarchaeotes to sustain aerobic hydrogenotrophic growth. However, physiological, genetic, and biochemical studies are needed to confirm this and describes its properties.

fields.function: Directly couples oxidation of H<sub>2</sub> to reduction of F<sub>420</sub> during hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis. Reverse reaction proposed to occur during methylotrophic methanogenesis. Electrons flow between H<sub>2</sub>-activating hydrogenase subunits to F<sub>420</sub> reductase subunit.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Methanogenic environments such as anoxic soils, marine sediments, and gastrointestinal tracts
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Encoded in all hydrogenotrophic methanogens
fields.subunit_description:
FrhA (hydrogenase large subunit)
FrhG (hydrogenase small subunit)
FrhB (F420 reductase subunit)
fields.notes: This subgroup also includes a small lineage of enzymes in Thermococci. As this order does not synthesize F<sub>420</sub>, these hydrogenases presumably couple H<sub>2</sub> oxidation to the reduction of another flavin or nicotinamide compound.

fields.function: Directly couples oxidation of NADPH to fermentative evolution of H<sub>2</sub>. Reverse reaction may also occur. Some complexes controversially proposed to harbour sulfhydrogenase activity.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Diverse soil and aquatic environments
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Encoded in multiple diverse bacterial and archaeal phyla
fields.subunit_description:
HyhL (hydrogenase large subunit)
HyhS (hydrogenase small subunit)
HyhG (diaphorase catalytic subunit)
HyhB (diaphorase electron transfer subunit)
fields.notes: Despite the ubiquitous nature of this hydrogenase, the enzyme has only been purified from Pyrococcus furiosus. It remains unclear whether bacterial enzymes are also NADP+-specific.

fields.function: Bifurcates electrons from H<sub>2</sub> to heterodisulfide and ferredoxin. This is the final step in the Wolfe cycle of methanogenesis.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Methanogenic environments such as anoxic soils, marine sediments, and gastrointestinal tracts
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Encoded in most methanogens and sulfate-reducing bacteria
fields.subunit_description:
MvhA (hydrogenase large subunit)
MvhG (hydrogenase small subunit)
MvhD (iron-sulfur subunit)
MvhB (polyferredoxin subunit)
Forms complex with heterodisulfide reductase (HdrABC)

fields.function: Generates reductant for hydrogenotrophic carbon-fixation by directly coupling oxidation of H<sub>2</sub> to reduction of NAD. Also acts in reverse direction to catalyse fermentative NADH-dependent production of H<sub>2</sub>. Electrons flow between H<sub>2</sub>-activating hydrogenase subunits to NAD-activating diaphorase subunits.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Diverse soil and aquatic environments
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Encoded in diverse Proteobacteria and Cyanobacteria
fields.subunit_description:
HoxH (hydrogenase large subunit)
HoxY (hydrogenase small subunit)
HoxF (diaphorase catalytic subunit)
HoxU (diaphorase electron transfer subunit)
Photosynthetic bacteria also contain HoxE (iron-sulfur subunit)

fields.function: Directly couples formate oxidation to H2 evolution. It remains unclear whether this process can be coupled to proton-translocation through the transmembrane modules. Reverse reaction occurs in vitro but unresolved whether it occurs in vivo.
fields.ecosystem_distribution: Animal gastrointestinal tracts
fields.taxonomic_distribution: Encoded in Enterobacteria and several other Proteobacteria
fields.subunit_description:
HycE / HyfG (hydrogenase large subunit)
HycG / HyfI (hydrogenase small subunit)
HycF / HyfH (iron-sulfur protein)
HycB / HyfA (iron-sulfur protein)
HycC / HyfB (NuoL-like transmembrane adaptors)
HycD / HyfC (NuoH-like transmembrane adaptors)
Hyf-type enzymes additionally associated with three antiporter-like subunits (HyfD, HyfE, HyfF)
Loosely associated with formate dehydrogenase module (FdhF)
fields.notes: It remains to be resolved whether the formate hydrogenlyase is fermentative (proton-nontranslocating) or respiring (proton-translocating) complex. Based on structural analysis of Complex I suggests, it is possible that the NuoL-like and NuoM-like subunits are proton-translocating. It is likely that Hyf-like complexes can generate membrane potential through its antiporter-like subunits.

fields.function: Forms respiratory supercomplex that couples oxidation of low-potential carbon compounds to reduction of protons concomitant with Na<sup>+</sup> translocation. Electron-input modules include formate dehydrogenases, carbon monoxide dehydrogenases, and potentially glutamate synthases. Electrons flow through hydrogenase resulting in proton reduction to H<sub>2</sub>. The energy released is used to translocate Na<sup>+</sup> ions through Mrp-like antiporter subunits to generate a sodium-motive force.

fields.taxonomic_distribution: Encoded in Thermococci, Thermoprotei, and Thermodesulfovibrio

MchAB (NuoL-like transmembrane adaptors)

MchHIJKLMN (Mrp-like antiporter subunits)
Form functional complexes with formate dehydrogenases, carbon monoxide dehydrogenases, and glutamate synthases

fields.function: Unconfirmed role. May form respiratory complex that couples oxidation of formate to proton reduction. The energy generated is likely to be used to translocate protons through the antiporter-like subunits.

fields.function: Forms supercomplex that couples H<sub>2</sub> oxidation to ferredoxin reduction by utilising the sodium-motive force. The reduced ferredoxin generated can be used anaplerotically to replenish the Wolfe cycle of methanogenesis. While the reverse direction is energetically favourable, it is unclear whether it occurs physiologically.
